title: Portcullis
text:
A portcullis (from Old French "porte coleice", "sliding gate") is a heavy vertically-closing <a href="gate">gate</a> typically found in <a href="medieval%20fortification">medieval fortification</a>s, consisting of a latticed <a href="Grille%20%28architecture%29">grille</a> made of wood, metal, or a combination of the two, which slides down grooves inset within each jamb of the gateway.
Usage.
Portcullises fortified the entrances to many <a href="medieval">medieval</a> <a href="castle">castle</a>s, securely closing off the castle during time of attack or <a href="siege">siege</a>. Every portcullis was mounted in vertical grooves in the walls of the castle and could be raised or lowered quickly by means of <a href="chain">chain</a>s or <a href="rope">rope</a>s attached to an internal <a href="winch">winch</a>.
Portcullises had an advantage of gates in that they could be closed immediately at a time of crisis by a single guard.
Often, two portcullises to the main <a href="Gate">entrance</a> would be used. The one closer to the inside would be closed first, and then the one farther away. This was used to trap the enemy, and often, burning <a href="wood">wood</a> or fire-heated sand would be dropped onto them from the roof or <a href="murder-hole">murder-hole</a>s. <a href="Early%20thermal%20weapons%23Hot%20oil">Hot oil</a>, however, was not commonly used in this manner, contrary to popular belief, since oil was extremely expensive. <a href="Arrowslit">Arrowslit</a>s in the sides of the walls enabled <a href="archery">archers</a> and <a href="crossbow">crossbow</a>men to eliminate the trapped group of attackers.
In England, working portcullises survive at the <a href="Tower%20of%20London">Tower of London</a>, <a href="Monk%20Bar">Monk Bar</a>, York and <a href="Hever%20Castle">Hever Castle</a>, Kent and at the hotel conversion, <a href="Amberley%20Castle">Amberley Castle</a>. In Scotland, there is a working portcullis at <a href="Edinburgh%20Castle">Edinburgh Castle</a>.
Heraldry.
The portcullis was the heraldic badge of the <a href="House%20of%20Beaufort">House of Beaufort</a>, and the first Tudor king, <a href="Henry%20VII%20of%20England">Henry VII</a>, who was of matrilineal Beaufort descent, adapted both the portcullis and the <a href="Tudor%20rose">Tudor rose</a> into <a href="Royal%20Badges%20of%20England">Royal badges</a> of the <a href="House%20of%20Tudor">House of Tudor</a>. Since then, the portcullis has been a moderately common <a href="motif%20%28visual%20arts%29">motif</a> of English <a href="heraldry">heraldry</a>, especially that heraldry dating from the Tudor period. The heraldic office of <a href="Portcullis%20Pursuivant">Portcullis Pursuivant of Arms in Ordinary</a>, a junior <a href="officer%20of%20arms">officer of arms</a> in the <a href="College%20of%20Arms">College of Arms</a> at <a href="London">London</a>, dates from this period.
It is through <a href="Lord%20Charles%20Somerset">Lord Charles Somerset</a>, son of <a href="Henry%20Somerset%2C%205th%20Duke%20of%20Beaufort">The 5th Duke of Beaufort</a>, that the portcullis has found its way into several South African coats of arms. Somerset established several towns during his governorship at the then <a href="British%20Cape%20Colony">Cape Colony</a> and named them for his family. These include <a href="Worcester%2C%20South%20Africa">Worcester</a>, <a href="Somerset%20West">Somerset West</a>, <a href="Fort%20Beaufort">Fort Beaufort</a> and <a href="Beaufort%20West">Beaufort West</a>. Institutions that derive the portcullis from these arms include a school, chamber of commerce and a rugby club. Other (approximately 30) South African coats of arms that include a portcullis are not necessarily related to either <a href="Courtesy%20titles%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Lord</a> Charles Somerset or any of the towns named for and by him.
Although the <a href="Palace%20of%20Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a> served as the official <a href="royal%20residence">royal residence</a> for both Henry VII and <a href="Henry%20VIII%20of%20England">Henry VIII</a> until 1530, the current use of the portcullis as a symbol of the Palace and of <a href="Parliament%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Parliament</a> does not date from that time. Rather, the symbol was developed as part of <a href="Charles%20Barry">Sir Charles Barry</a>'s plans for the rebuilt Palace after <a href="Burning%20of%20Parliament">the original burned down</a> on 16 October 1834; he conceptualized the new Palace as a "legislative castle", and the symbol of a castle gate—i.e. a portcullis—fitted well with the scheme.
Since then, the portcullis has become the primary symbol of Parliament; an office building for <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Members of Parliament</a> (MPs), opened in 2001, is named "<a href="Portcullis%20House">Portcullis House</a>". During the 20th century, use of the portcullis as a symbol of Parliament spread beyond Britain and to the other <a href="Commonwealth%20realm">Commonwealth realm</a>s; for instance, the <a href="coat%20of%20arms%20of%20Canberra">coat of arms of Canberra</a> features a portcullis in its <a href="crest%20%28heraldry%29">crest</a>, preserving a connection between the British Parliament at Westminster and the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Australia">Australian Parliament</a> to which Canberra is home.
The badge, Coat of Arms and Flag of the <a href="Canada%20Border%20Services%20Agency">Canada Border Services Agency</a> all include a portcullis, symbolising the agency's role as Her Majesty's agents responsible for the border services of Canada. A portcullis was previously found on the <a href="Penny%20%28British%20decimal%20coin%29">British one penny coin</a> and on the <a href="Threepence%20%28British%20coin%29">pre-decimal thrupenny bit</a>; this has since been replaced by a section of the <a href="royal%20coat%20of%20arms%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Royal Arms of the United Kingdom</a>. It was also featured in the now-defunct <a href="HM%20Customs%20and%20Excise">HM Customs and Excise</a> in the United Kingdom and still appears in the rank insignia for the various grades of commissioner in the <a href="Australian%20Border%20Force">Australian Border Force</a>.
